citation.article-title: Rhodoglobus vestalii gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel psychrophilic organism isolated from an Antarctic Dry Valley lake
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Rhodoglobus (Rho.do.glo′bus. Gr. n. rhodon the rose; L. masc. n. globus ball; N.L. masc. n. rhodoglobus red ball).
Cells are aerobic, Gram-positive, easily decolourized, motile and non-spore-forming.
Colonies are smooth, round, convex, non-slimy, translucent, reddish and small (2–3 mm in diameter).
Individual cells are slender rods (mean cell size of 0·15–0·2×1–1·2 μm), with bulbous protuberances (mean diameter 0·8 μm) seen at all stages of growth.
Cell walls contain ornithine as the diagnostic amino acid.
Predominant fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, anteiso-C17 : 0 and iso-C16 : 0.
Major menaquinones are MK-11 and MK-12.
The type species is Rhodoglobus vestalii.
